newsitem.title: ITALY: SOCCER-NAPOLI'S COACH LOOKS BACK TO THE FUTURE.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-NAPOLI'S COACH LOOKS BACK TO THE FUTURE.

text.p: Napoli coach Gigi Simoni bemoaned the death of the "beautiful game" on Friday as he prepared his team for another display of old-style Italian soccer.

Simoni has brought a sparkle back to the game -- and the crowds back to the San Paolo stadium in Naples -- by shunning the zonal play that has become the mark of Italian soccer for more traditional individual flair.
The result -- Napoli lie third in serie A, behind Vicenza on goal difference and six points adrift of leaders Juventus.
They travel to Fiorentina on Sunday in their drive to win a championship that has eluded them since the glory days of Diego Maradona, who captained Napoli to their only two titles in 1987 and 1990.
"I defend the soccer of the past not out of tradition but because it represents what I believe in," Simoni, who came to Napoli from Cremonese this season, told Gazzetta dello Sport.
"If you kill fantasy it's a bit like killing soccer. You imprison it, make it boring and empty the stadiums," he said.
"Our job is to entertain. Soccer is not just about someone who's good at drawing diagrams on a blackboard. It's not in the hands of draughtsmen of strategy and tactics, a line here, a cross there.
"When I was a boy I fell for a sport that had fantasy, that got you excited about a move, a touch of the ball, the way the game sang. That's my kind of football," Simoni said.
Simoni will have all his players available for Sunday's game but could leave Brazilian midfielder Beto out of the side as punishment for a late return to Naples from Christmas at home.
Newspapers reported on Friday that the player also faced a 15 million lire ($1,000) fine for his unauthorised two-day absence.
Fiorentina are looking for their second successive win at home after beating Cagliari 2-0 on December 22 before Italian soccer stopped for the Christmas and New Year break.
Owner Vittorio Cecchi Gori has told the eighth-placed club that he expects three wins in a row from their opening games of 1997.
Midfielders Stefan Schwartz and Sandro Cois are both suspended but the foreign trio of Argentine Gabriel Batistuta, Sweden Kennet Andersson and Portugal's Rui Costa are all available.
"The game against Napoli is difficult and important," Batistuta said. "It's a new year and we have to get off on the right foot."
